title: When will an NBA game next be played?
preds: Positives by current players and Florida, Texas, California and New York’s numbers. Many players live in those states in off season, especially Florida and Texas with no state income taxes.
Only one week to go. Current plan is for NBA to resume on 31 July 2020.
Still no possibility of before  1 July 2020
"No games are expected to take place until July 30." https://www.espn.com/nba/story/_/id/29341659/concern-nba-grows-coronavirus-cases-spike-florida

"The NBA needed months to work out the details of its planned restart in a 'bubble' at Walt Disney World near Orlando, Fla., which is slated to begin in late July and will be governed by 113 pages of health and safety protocols." https://www.wsj.com/articles/coronavirus-surge-throws-another-curve-at-baseballs-restart-plans-11592600803
Can't get it organized that fast.
Not everyone has a home gym, even if they are professional athletes.
Current news consistent with an after July 1 date.
Reopening plan is for July 30th and players are still even unsure of that date. 100+ player phone call on Friday 6/13 where players were expressing concerns.
"The NBA is full steam ahead for a July 31 restart." https://www.npr.org/2020/06/11/874311586/bubbles-and-empty-seats-pro-sports-forge-ahead-with-comebacks-despite-the-pandem
Already NBA is planning to start at end of July
Because the NBA has already announced that it will not play games before July 1!

"Jackson was a close friend of George Floyd, who drew national attention when he was killed by police in Minneapolis on May 25, 2020. Jackson received media attention for an impassioned speech he gave at a protest rally in Minnesota. In it, he stated, "I'm here because they're not gonna demean the character of George Floyd, my twin." Jackson and Floyd called each other "Twin" due to their similar physical appearance." https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stephen_Jackson#Personal_life_and_reputation I just bumped into this by chance.

Latest word is that the first game won't be until July 31st at the earliest [1]. Holding current. [1] https://dknation.draftkings.com/2020/6/2/21278548/nba-season-2020-return-date-july-31-restart-playoff-format-timeline-update-news-rumors
The NBA has approved a plan to return on July 31. https://www.msn.com/en-us/sports/nba/nba-set-to-return-july-31-with-22-teams/ar-BB1533oZ

NBA has approved its plan for the resumption of play. This article says the expected start date is July 22nd. [1]  [1] https://www.cbssports.com/nba/news/nba-board-of-governors-approves-22-team-plan-to-finish-the-2019-20-season-at-disney-world/

Whatever the NBA's disclosure of tonight will be, it would be premature to resolve this question before 1 July 2020.
The explicit question is "When will an NBA game next be played?" (An exhibition game would not count.)
The question was not, when the NBA Season will be resumed, or when the NBA finals will take place. There may come a few occasions in which an official though off-season NBA game may happen, since the NBA organization will have to find a solution for all those teams which will not qualify for the finals and thus would run idle for nine months otherwise.
To me it is also rational to expect the NBA to schedule an intermediate NBA game for the good cause/Charity (e.g. pandemic relief, the Floyd family) before 1 July 2020, which may have the format of an All-Star-Game. (The only question would be, if this counts as an 'exhibition game' as well...) The NBA as well as other sports need to show what they stand for, and what they are in aid of. The Tiger Woods/Peyton Manning vs. Phil Mickelson/Tom Brady golf match at the Medalist Golf Club, Hobe Sound, (FL) on 24 May 2020 could be a model. https://edition.cnn.com/2020/05/24/us/how-to-watch-tiger-woods-phil-mickelson-match-trnd/index.html

"Sources: NBA to approve plan for 22-team return with eight regular-season games" "Teams will begin training at team sites in July and advance to full training camps in Orlando in July, sources said." https://www.espn.com/nba/story/_/id/29260860/sources-nba-approve-plan-22-team-return-eight-regular-season-games
Guess July is when (if?) they are looking to restart.
Seeing many references to late July for the next games. Vote is this Thursday that will figure out the format [1]. [1] https://apnews.com/7afdf5818cc05b0882d620be66770e14

https://apnews.com/7afdf5818cc05b0882d620be66770e14
They seem not to be talking about anything earlier than mid-July.  We should believe them.

"The NBA is in early discussions to restart its season in late July at Disney's ESPN sports complex in Florida, the league announced Saturday." https://www.axios.com/nba-coronavirus-disney-b0052bc8-b24a-4d53-ac36-4d49bb03d656.html

The NBA has entered into exploratory conversations with the Walt Disney Company about restarting the remainder of its season at Disney's ESPN Wide World of Sports Complex in Orlando, Florida, in late July, NBA spokesperson Mike Bass said Saturday. https://www.espn.com/nba/story/_/id/29213517/nba-talks-resume-play-disney-espn-wide-world-sports-complex
Negotions are for July at this point

This article effectively rules out return to action before July: https://www.espn.co.uk/nba/story/_/id/29200984/nba-teams-expecting-guidelines-june-1-players-return "The league is discussing a step-by-step plan for a resumption of the season that includes an initial two-week recall of players into team marketplaces for a period of quarantine, one to two weeks of individual workouts at team facilities, and a two- to three-week formal training camp, sources told ESPN." "Barring an unforeseen turn of events, many NBA owners, executives and National Basketball Players Association elders believe commissioner Adam Silver will green-light the return to play in June -- with games expected to resume sometime before the end of July, sources said."

It seems they will have a tournament play mode just to finish the season. Disney World/Orlando/FL seems to be one step ahead of other locations. The date of "further notice" and maybe the next game seems to be close. https://thehill.com/blogs/blog-briefing-room/news/498951-disney-world-clear-front-runner-for-resumed-nba-games-report

Commissioner is saying 2-4 weeks for a decision and if it's a yes then 3-6 weeks for pre-resumption training, logistics etc.   So range is 5-10 weeks.  There is a slight chance of the next game occurring by 30 June.  Updating forecast to reflect non-zero chance of NBA in June.  Revisit around May 28th.
WIll not finish discussions until June.  Proposal from league is for July. https://nypost.com/2020/05/12/nba-players-poll-could-hold-key-to-season-restart-plans/
Commissioner Adam Silver said if games resume, they would last “significantly later than June,” which would push back the start of a new season in the fall.

Updated forecast: Some teams reopening facilities and beginning to get permission to test asymptomatic players and staff, an important step. Different restrictions and measures in different states, and differential impacts of COVID, mean some teams will still be waiting longer than others, and will hinder restart. Very unlikely to see games in May - the rest of the teams still haven't returned to facilities and need testing capabilities. Commissioner also recently said return-to-play training camps should be 3 weeks at minimum, which effectively rules out May. 'Bubble' sites still being considered (Vegas and Orlando frontrunners). In Germany, the Bundesliga is scheduled to restart next week. Demonstrates that it is possible to hold sporting competitions in current climate (provided it does go ahead). NBA may wait and see how that turns out?

"NBA finally appears ready to reopen its practice facilities in areas with relaxed stay-at-home guidelines. The league has informed teams that it will do so on May 8 'pending new developments' ...The most recently reported plan to bring basketball back involved a 25-day preparation period in which players would work out individually for 11 days before coming together as teams for a 14-day training camp." https://www.cbssports.com/nba/news/coronavirus-nba-to-reopen-practice-facilities-in-states-with-eased-stay-at-home-guidelines-may-8-per-report/

States are opening sooner than I anticipated and plans on how to contain teams in “bubble” environments means games could start sooner than I originally predicted, which is why I increased likelihood in June.
If the season "resumes" June 1st, the first game could be played July 1st at earliest. Resuming in July 1st would allow for completion of the 19-20 season by September.

This years season is over. The entire events driven business model needs changed to accommodate the current climate of fear-based decisions. Most sports and live entertainment will only recover by 60% at most for 2 years or until a vaccine is proved and scaled out.

As of today (4/29)  there have been no indicators that the teams are practicing as a squad. Even if games were allowed to happen immediately there would presumably be a few weeks of practicing and re-conditioning time needed before full play resumes. June is a remote possibility because the early infections among players initiated significant testing and possible immunity. And of course the league has expressed willingness to be flexible with previous schedules in order to recoup some lost revenue.

Workouts for players in states with easing of restrictions will be returning to workouts starting May 8th at the earliest [1]. IL has stay-at-home orders until May 30th [2] and MA until the 18th. From this, it seems unlikely they are going to start playing games before July. [1] https://bleacherreport.com/articles/2888980-nba-teams-reportedly-concerned-fans-wont-be-able-to-attend-games-in-2020-21
[2] https://www.nbcchicago.com/news/coronavirus/these-places-businesses-can-reopen-under-illinois-modified-stay-at-home-order/2260626/
[3] https://www.nbcboston.com/news/local/gov-baker-to-provide-update-on-coronavirus-in-mass-3/2114910/
This season is likely to be done.
4/27 update.  They might play without fans.

NBA discussions on opening back up are moving forward and targeting date a May 8th date for players to return to facilities and practice in a limited capacity (https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/nba/2020/04/27/nba-targets-may-8-for-individual-player-workouts/3035594001/). Bill Simmons & Ryen Russillo discuss NBA return on last night's podcast.  May is basically impossible, end of June is likely (https://www.theringer.com/the-bill-simmons-podcast/2020/4/27/21237981/bad-boy-pistons-nfl-draft-lessons-nba-summer-news-and-suns-bulls-1993-with-ryen-russillo)
Assume that at a certain point the NBA would rather have a full season for 2020-21. Camps usually open in September, so 2020 season would need to be done by then plus a break.
Teams can go back to training facilities in some states and they are looking for alternatives for other teams. Can the season restart soon?
NBA allowing the opening of practice facilities May 1st, increased likelihood of games in may/June
Late to forecast, but there will need to be ramp up and a place to hold the games. Neither which have started.

The Leader Of The Free World has expressed the belief that he must (and can) make sports operate again; he says he's tired of watching games from fourteen years ago.   See Act 5, Scene 5 of The Scottish Play, for what this signifies and why.

"various executives and team medical personnel have been discussing possible protocols to get players ready for games...One of the ideas that has been proposed is a 25-day program for players to go through before they resume game play." https://www.espn.com/nba/story/_/id/29027466/25-day-program-part-potential-return-plan-discussed-nba-sources-say Given that the announcement of something like this 25-day program has not even occurred yet, I think a resumption of NBA games is not likely to occur before June.

Adam Silver has said no decision before 1 May, and even then they may not be ready to decide anything.
Availability of rapid-result testing described as a critical hurdle to pass - still in the exploratory phase, but with rapid pace of medical research it might be developed quickly? Even if it is developed NBA would need to wait behind health workers and other key workers given shortage of testing in the country. https://www.espn.co.uk/nba/story/_/id/29003625/nba-players-union-assessing-potential-covid-rapid-test-options  Aside from testing, still major logistical issues. These articles give some interesting examples on how games might be played (e.g. a central site for all NBA players to stay for rest of season): https://bleacherreport.com/articles/2882528-how-the-nba-could-resume-amid-coronavirus-shutdown
https://www.cnbc.com/2020/03/26/coronavirus-how-the-nba-is-planning-to-save-its-season.html
These are predicated on the fact that it will happen without fans...there's no way it happens with fans in this timeframe.
Assuming quarantine measures are strictly enforced over at least a 14 day period, this may allow for games to begin again, albeit at low capacity.

With NBA being the first professional sports league to shut down, I think they will be given one of the first opportunities to come back. Even with that said, I see June being the earliest possibility with July much more likely. NBA has an advantage in that they can play in any weather condition so rushing back is not as important as it is for baseball.

Holding strong that the current season won't be cancelled and will likely resume before July 1 (https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/nba/2020/04/06/coronavirus-nba-adam-silver-suspended-season-no-decision-april/2959212001/)
They could have a game with no fans in the seat but with TV.
we have a long way to go yet

"The best-case scenario is looking like a late June/early July start-up with the idea of the 2020-21 season not commencing until Christmas" yet the NBA has "still not ruled out cancelling the season altogether." https://nypost.com/2020/03/30/the-playoff-scenarios-nba-is-discussing-for-hopeful-return/

Basing on day-to-day COVID-19 cases dropping back to below current levels for a sustained period of time. Initial statistical breakdown on this is a fairly rudimentary exponential growth w/ decay + intervention accounting (Will continue looking to improve this model)
Pushing back in response to federal government extending social distancing guidelines
same rationale as MLB but smaller groups and more possible testing.

Due to the current outbreak in the United States of the COVID - 19 and it's rapid spread, I believe that the virus will not be under control before July 1, 2020 allowing the NBA to start playing again.

Reason for later date:
- US are currently in exponential growth phase of new COVID-19 cases
- while ~1/3 of the country is in "lock-down", the spread of the virus has not (yet) been answered as agressively as in Europe
- denial of the government of the magnitude could lead to widespread infections before further measures to contain the virus are taken, therefore delaying the combat of the virus
- unlikely that NBA will re-open (even without spectators) before number of new infections recedes substantially, which is hard to see over next 2 months unless country-wide lock down is implemented immediately
- even after stabilization of numbers expectation is that NBA will wait and see to avoid potential further infections driven by re-opening (legal risk when re-opening too early) Reasons for opening before 01 July 2020:
- pressure from sponsors
- games without spectators could be played if players and staff get tested frequently once number of new infections are reduced
- NBA finals were originally planned to start on 04 June; combined with long summer break this could motivate the NBA to introduce shortened playoffs beginning of June and then shortening the summer break (given players can already rest now)
Mark Cuban is saying maybe mid-May.
Behind the NBA are the sponsors pushing to resume the game at the most reasonable time, but major changes in the playoff schedule will be made.

What we know:  NBA has suspended games for at least 30 days, beginning March 11.  So far, 14 people within the NBA community, including at least 10 players, have tested positive for COVID-19. 
What we assume:  1) NBA would prefer to salvage the season.  2) NBA teams and players would fall under state quarantines, social-distancing, and curfews - so if the NBA resumed play, but a state prohibited being outside residence after a certain hour or groups larger than 10, this would prevent an NBA game from being played.   
Unknown:   What is the drop dead date for resuming league play in order to have a playoffs?  ESPN sources report that the league has asked teams for building availability dates through the end of August, an indicator that if the season resumes the league is willing to consider stretching it deep into the summer. 
https://www.nba.com/article/2020/03/21/nba-adam-silver-considering-all-options-ap
https://www.nba.com/article/2020/03/12/adam-silver-letter-nba-fans

A mid to late June game is a 'best-case scenario', considering CDC guidelines of 8 weeks with no gatherings of >50 people. https://www.espn.com/nba/story/_/id/28923583/adam-silver-lays-conditions-nba-return-mulls-charity-game-diversion Probably to be delayed as cases rise further.
Trump wants to open the economy in April. Might have an effect on these decisions. In addition a quick 45 minute test result test is coming on-line. Tweeking just a little.
Same reason as other sporting events are cancelled around the world.

https://www.si.com/nba/2020/03/21/coronavirus-testing-sports-leagues-could-resume
https://www.si.com/nba/2020/03/21/coronavirus-testing-sports-leagues-could-resume
Upshot: while they can test players they could not test all fans coming in. Could resume as TV only to complete season if new test okayed. Otherwise June or later.

NY state don't expect cases to peak for 30 days which is end April. This cross will like run through summer and beyond. NBA were proactive about po to ordering their players and won't go back early unnecessarily.

South Korea went through the peak of the pandemic around Feb 28. New cases have been below 100 for several days. It can be said that they have the outbreak under control now. The KBL is discussing resuming games behind closed doors in April as are other leagues in Japan and China. https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2020/03/19/sports/basketball/ap-bkovirus-outbreak-asia-leagues.html
After reaching peak new cases in the US (April?), it's possible to put a best case scenario date on the first NBA game, based on the South Korea example.
government will make use of civic buildings
With players still testing positive, along with a slow-to-peak danger zone, it’s unlikely we’ll see any basketball this season.

the nba is distributed across the country. the country is experiencing COVID at different rates and as it subsides in some areas that are hit the hardest now (NY, CA, WA), other areas will start to experience the effects. So if exhibition games do not count, then we're looking at a long wait until the next games which could only occur when life gets back to normal somehow, which wont be for months.

With many schools and governments shutdown until end of March/early April there is no way it stats before April 1st, and very unlikely that it starts before April 30th.  Seeing that current players are still testing positive that pushes these dates back another 2 weeks from today which puts it into early April at a minimum. Commissioner Adam Silver recently laid out conditions for return on 3/18/2020 (https://www.espn.com/nba/story/_/id/28923583/adam-silver-lays-conditions-nba-return-mulls-charity-game-diversion).  There have been talks to shift the season towards a Christmas to end of August schedule (https://www.talkbasket.net/76643-nba-commissioner-statement-on-moving-the-nbas-start-date-to-around-christmas & https://www.msn.com/en-us/sports/nba/why-nba-should-permanently-shift-start-of-season-to-christmas-day/ar-BB11q7Ry) and this may be the way the NBA does that while also salvaging the current season, and would require the playoffs for the current season starting in June.
The US is at the start of a 3 month run on the virus.  But that point no one will have any money and there will be more risk of social breakdown, so sport will not be top of the agenda

The rapid increase in cases in China stopped roughly 30 days after end of January when it became apparent for the whole world that the decease is highly contagious and somewhat deadly. We saw similar jump in concern and steps in self-isolation in mid March with full shut downs starting on March 22nd. Given that we have more information about the decease and increasingly ways to treat it, i would expect that the number of infected cases to peak somewhere between April 15th and 22nd. Since everyone will be looking to get back to normality as soon as possible and we should have testing methods to see if any of the players are sick we should be able to get back to games by mid-May (even if without audiences). NBA may chose to run a shortened schedule before starting playoffs in the beginning of June.
Very high salaries = palyer value, close contact sport
Likely wont start again until next season

US pandemic spread just started with +/- 14.000 cases (source: https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/country/us/). Considering the hesitation of the US government on a nation-wide lockdown, it could be possible the transmission will reach far more people faster. Taking into account China has stabilised the number of transmissions with 2 months of unimaginable lockdown for Western countries, the US might have to deal with it for at least 3 months, potentially longer.

considering the costs involved especially from tv rights etc, NBA and the players will have to reach an agreement to resume the season without spectators but with regular COVID-19 testing for each player/employee of each team. End of June is >3 months from now and I expect govt imposed social distancing measures to be relaxed when the rate of infections starts to slow down considerably. Players would have to agree to be in a sort of team isolation status (limited contact with outside world at least at the beginning) in order to save the season
Judging rate of spread and the uncertainty surrounding it it's not very likely for the NBA to resume before July 1st 2020
The number of US infected will continue to grew dramatically through at least May, therefore, no games before June 1st and more likely none before July 1st.

If they choose to have the game without spectators, they might be able to go ahead and make up for lost revenue by being one of the few big events on television and probably getting high views. But it’s vastly preferable to play with an audience, and there are many people needed to support games. Breaking social distancing would be a terrible choice and many employees would probably resist, and it may not even be allowed by the government at that point. The virus will not be contained until there is a vaccine, which will take more than a year.
CDC guidance on large gatherings and the need to secure arena space quickly may delay things a while
Covid will still be rampaging through US economy.

The exponential curve currently in the US and the drastic measures required for COVID19 to get under control (actions taken by China and currently in progress in Italy) require 1-2 months before completing the cycle. With testing ramping up, and a need to protect the immunocompromised, and a vaccine still months away, the chances are great that the NBA will postpone for months to come.

Do not believe quarantine will be lifted until at least May 1st, with likelihood it is later. The longer the delay the less likely the season will be resumed at all as it would impact readiness for 20/21 season.

NBA wants to play - a) make money; b) address boredom; c) express american pride. They want to play as soon as they can, even if it is without fans. By June we'll have a much better sense for how to handle COVID interventions and be able to manage it well. I currently believe expert estimates of COVID infections do not fully account for interventions and human innovation in the face of disaster. I am tracking ft.com and ourworldindata.org stats on covid infections and deaths.
Training facilities are closed. It will take a while for teams to figure out format of season. I do however see charity games and exhibitions being held end of may or beginning of June.
corona may take 3-6 months untill we recover to the normal life habbits.
Similar to my other answer - I see little chance of any major sporting events taking place before the end of the summer.
I think COVID-19 will go on for 3-6 months at least, at a level that travel and meeting in large groups will still be limited at least that long.

Given how virulent this virus is, I just don't see how there can be any games before July 1st, as the CDC order lasts 8 weeks, to the first week of May,  and then teams would probably need to scrimmage some practice games before playing the playoffs, as there's no reason to even re-start the regular season, not with the chance that playing could result in spreading infection and causing further quarantine.  That puts us into early June at best, and likely there will be another problem, unforeseen, that crops up, like the fact there are reports of re-infection, not only in China, but I read in two other countries as well (I think Italy and Japan, but not sure).

This article seems to suggest the earliest this could occur is mid-May. [1] In addition, the CDC advised that for the next two month no gatherings of over 50 people, which probably rules out the NBA until may as well. In addition, at least 7 NBA players have now tested positive for the coronavirus, putting further impetus on the league to stay cautious and on top of this.  This article suggests mid-June is a best case scenario. My thinking aligns with their thinking. It will take probably 8-10 weeks for this to sort out, and then a further month before things really kick off again. NBA will probably take it slow, but could potentially do regular season play with no fans, and then let the fans in for the playoffs. That would allow a June start date.  [1] https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/nba/2020/03/16/coronavirus-nba-potential-return-options-obstacles-remain/5056621002/
[2] https://www.espn.com/nba/story/_/id/28911848/when-nba-return-latest-updates-amid-coronavirus-suspension

CDC has suggested large gatherings be scrapped (https://www.politico.com/news/2020/03/15/cdc-recommends-suspending-mass-gatherings-for-8-weeks-1310) for eight weeks which suggests there won't be any play till mid May.

It is  more than likely that the season is either cancelled, shortened or some other format comes into play.  There may not be a game this year.   Players travel huge distances, their insurers are likely to deny cover at some point.   As social distancing comes into effect there will be a longer impact, particularly as the US is behind many nations in infection and detection levels.

The CDC is recommending cancelling events of 50 or more participants for the next 8 weeks:
https://www.cnn.com/2020/03/15/health/us-coronavirus-sunday-updates/index.html

Games will be held in closed doors, people at home need some entertainment!!! Also do you guys really think any free western society will stay shut down for months on end? Within 2-3 weeks, people will get sick of quarantine something will need to be done to keep them distracted, at home.
Either they reschedule some of the remaining regular season games in April - May then have the playoffs, or they determine that the season will not continue and the next season will be the next game.
the show must go on. until may the crisis is over

I think the NBA could play without fans for a while but since a number of players have tested positive they'll be slow to get back on the court. They suspended very quickly so I think there is a conservative approach. They're getting close to playoffs so I think a scenario could be, play a few more regular season games to get everyone even and do the playoffs as early in May as possible.

By early May the COVID-19 outbreak will be reasonably well understood and will be controllable within the population of NBA players.  The players can be tested and their conditions and contacts managed given the value of playing out the season, even in empty arenas.  The NBA can still run just on television.  I do not think owners or players want to give up the season and the monies attached to it.
If any games are played soon I'll assume they will be in empty stadiums. That seems possible.  All the folks stuck at home need something to watch!

The NBA is willing to sit this out as long as necessary. We're talking about a sport played inside arenas, so weather isn't a factor. They can (and have been known to) pick up when they can with limited impact to attendance/revenue. https://www.nba.com/article/2020/03/11/coronavirus-pandemic-causes-nba-suspend-season
The teams will practice social distancing AND experience significant infection
Actual infection rate may matter less in this question than say - the cost of sanitizing an entire arena, protecting talent/property and dealing with Civil Liability issues.
90 days if done right for it to begin to fizzle out.
I think the initial shock of the pandemic will wear off and the NBA will find a way to wrap up the season.
Again, an initial hunch. A lot can and will change and there are several moving parts to examine.
They may sit out the rest of the regular season, but I don't think they'll miss out on playoffs, which are scheduled for April 18.
Season will be cancelled. Plus, the talk about players not getting paid will blow the whole thing up.
Given the NBA season is mostly complete, and given television revenue, the league will likely hold some kind of games when player health can be guaranteed.
